The date of the first confirmed cases: Both the United States and South Korea confirmed their first cases of COVID-19 on January 20, 2020. This information was supported by official statements from the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
Origin and travel history of the patient: The first case in South Korea was a 35-year-old woman who had been living in Wuhan, China, where the outbreak originated. The first case in the United States was a 35-year-old man who had recently returned from Wuhan, China. These details were reported by the National IHR Focal Point for South Korea and the CDC.
Laboratory confirmation of infection: Both countries conducted tests to confirm the presence of the novel coronavirus in the patients. The CDC confirmed the positive test result for the U.S. patient using real-time reverse-transcriptase–polymerase-chain-reaction (rRT-PCR) assay. The details of the laboratory confirmation were mentioned in the New England Journal of Medicine.
Different outcomes and response strategi: Despite having their first cases on the same day, the United States and South Korea took different approaches to treating the disease and experienced different outcomes. As of March 23, 2020, the United States had over 35,000 cases, while South Korea had less than 9,000 cases. This information highlights the different results and strategies employed by the two countries in managing the pandemic.
